awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CAS: Electrochemical Approaches to Sustainable Dinitrogen Fixation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Chemical Catalysis (CAT) Program in the Division of Chemistry, supports a collaborative team consisting of Professors Alexander Miller at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill; Alan Goldman, Frank Felder and Gal Hochman at Rutgers University; and Robert Crabtree, Patrick Holland, and James Mayer at Yale University. The team is designing new ways to convert nitrogen into ammonia. Ammonia is the precursor to many useful materials, including most fertilizers, latex, nylon, explosives and some electrolytes for batteries. Present day methods for making ammonia are energy intensive and rely on fossil fuels as a source of hydrogen. Acting on preliminary results, the team is developing a processes that uses water as the hydrogen source. Atmospheric nitrogen, which comprises ~78% of the air we breathe, is the other feedstock. Key to this work are new molybdenum- and rhenium-based catalysts that cleave atmospheric nitrogen into nitrogen atoms. Graduate students receive hands-on training on calculations and laboratory techniques to prepare them for future careers in energy and sustainability. In addition to the laboratory work, the faculty-student teams are working with economists to test the feasibility of diverse approaches to advanced manufacturing. Outreach programs in three states are underway to educate the public about nitrogen fixation. 

The proposed collaborative research project targets the discovery and mechanistic study of new molecular catalysts for electrochemical N2 reduction. With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Chemistry Division, Professor Miller of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Professor Goldman, Felder and Hochman of Rutgers University, and Professors Crabtree, Holland, and Mayer of Yale University are developing catalysts capable of electrocatalytic NH3 production via direct N2 splitting to form metal nitride complexes. Detailed studies afford mechanistic insight that is guiding the design of new molybdenum and rhenium complexes and reaction conditions for electrocatalysis. The diversity of systems and methods available through this collaborative approach are being leveraged to generate broadly applicable insights into the properties of transition metal complexes that favor N2 splitting and protonation of nitride intermediates to yield NH3 under conditions amenable to electrocatalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research project expanded fundamental understanding of the factors that influence dinitrogen (N2) binding, cleavage, and conversion to ammonia by transition metal complexes. Researchers received training in a range of chemical techniques, engaged with economists studying renewable electricity markets, and developed educational materials for middle- and high-school students and teachers.

The chemical research focused on N2 fixation via the splitting of end-on bridging N2 complexes into nitrido intermediates (M≡N) that are further reduced to ammonia. Combined experimental and computational studies addressed the fundamental question of when N2 binds in a terminal versus bridging fashion. This insight enabled the further development of a molecular orbital theory method for establishing a meaningful Lewis structure for bridging N2 complexes. This general method enables predictions of structure and reactivity, guiding catalyst designs. A key finding is that the electronic structure is the primary controller of N2 splitting reactivity, revising the prevailing wisdom that degree of electron richness of the metal center is the major determinant.

To spur the development of electrochemical ammonia synthesis, the mechanism of electrochemical N2 splitting and nitride reduction to ammonia was studied. Molybdenum and rhenium complexes were investigated, revealing a common occurrence of “over-reduction” near the electrode surface, followed by chemical redox reactions away from the electrode.

Dinitrogen cleavage to form metal nitride complexes has been proposed as a key step in N2 fixation catalysis. In most cases, this reaction proceeds from a bridging N2 complex with 10 electrons in the pi-symmetry orbitals of the MNNM core. Research in this project revealed examples of rhenium and molybdenum complexes that form bridging complexes with unusual electronic structures, which still readily split into nitride complexes. Factors determining the reactivity of the nitride intermediates were elucidated. Further studies led to new catalysts for N2 reduction to NH3 using chemical reductants, which were studied using electrochemical methods.

Economic studies focused on how emerging and fluctuating renewable electricity markets might impact future electrochemical ammonia processes. Renewable energy sources (e.g. solar) have substantial fluctuations, resulting in supply/demand mismatches. We have quantified how electrochemical N2 fixation can take economic advantage of such mismatches and serve as a valuable load-leveler for the electrical grid. We showed that an electrochemical N2 reduction process, with sufficient catalytic efficiency, would be substantially more economical than Haber-Bosch N2 reduction with electrochemically generated H2 .

The broader impacts of the work include research findings, training outcomes, and educational activities. Nitrogen fixation catalysis impacts the global agriculture and food sectors as well as the energy sector, but current thermal methods release massive amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Building fundamental knowledge will lead to electrochemical alternatives that use only sustainable energy and water to reduce N2. The ammonia produced could be used for fertilizer, replacing current Haber-Bosch production or even allowing decentralized small-scale local production. On a potentially even larger scale, electrochemical N2 reduction could be applied to the storage and transportation of renewable energy. The project trained 5 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students in interdisciplinary and collaborative science. A key educational activity was the launch of nitrogenfixers.org, a portal for teachers and students to learn about electrochemistry and fertilizer chemistry. Through sending kits to students and teachers, training teachers at workshops, participating in summer outreach activities, and visiting schools to present demonstrations, the broader community learned about the role of chemical catalysis in ammonia synthesis for agriculture and energy applications.


Last Modified: 11/10/2023
Modified by: Alan S Goldman
